rComments: Probably the least favourite prof I've had. Shallow, disorganized lectures, tough, nonsensical grading criteria, and she's rude to boot! Poorly planned syllabus (who gives you a week to write your final paper?) and course materials (who teaches nothing but World War I and II period novels in a class on contemporary literature?).

She is one tough cookie. You better know the answers, otherwise, you will be belittled in front of an entire class. Be ready for deep reading, every aspect of the text is exhaustingly overanalyzed. Be prepared for lectures that sound impressive but in hindsight are filled with big words meaning small things.
teacherRatingTags: ['Lecture heavy', 'Graded by few things', 'Get ready to read']

rComments: Her lectures are so uninspiring and oblivious that one wonders why we're paying to listen to her. Honestly, if I thought UofT would even hear my appeal, I'd ask for a refund. The TAs were kind and smart. Too bad they didn't teach us.

Her lectures are so uninspiring and oblivious that one wonders why we're paying for. Honestly, if I thought UofT would even hear my appeal, I'd ask for a refund. The TAs were kind and smart. Too bad they didn't teach us.

There is a reason why a class of 70+ dropped to 40 by the end of the semester, and it is not only attributable to laziness, which I am sure is what she tells herself. She is so unkind and her interpretations so obvious that you would be better off watching Youtube reviews of the books. I stuck it out but not sure why.

This professor was THE worst professor that I have ever encountered in my entire University of Toronto career. Avoid at all costs, she lowers the grades from the marks of the TA by around 5% just because she wants to. The TAs that I encountered were lovely but I just couldn't get around the fact that she did not care about her students.
Professor Salih is available to help if you seek her out and her lectures are amazing. I am so thankful to have been in her class.

Her analysis of novels are either convoluted or so cliche you can just look at sparknotes, but ironically if your paper doesn't consist of 100% original thought then be ready to receive a C. She has no late policy, grades very harshly, and it is impossible to reach her outside of class since she rarely ever checks her email.
She is a strong professor with high expectations. She demonstrated interest in her students and paaion for the texts. A very good teacher.

The worst professor I've ever had! The points she made regarding the texts were either embarassingly obvious or bizarre and baseless. Her tests were unfair. Marks were extremely low. She has no capacity for empathy. 75% of the students either dropped the course or stopped coming to class. The TA's were awful as well.

Her points are wishy-washy, uninsightful. She seems to harbour hate for teaching and her students (the fact she has no office hours or late policy should give you an idea of how considerate and empathetic she is); her lateness policy  to hate her

Very interesting and stimulating class. Learned a lot from it. She tends to politicizie a lot of the novels, but that's the method if one is to engage texts with postcolonial lens. Otherwise, she is rather strict in marking essays, but don't let that deter you. She is a great professor.

Unfortunately Salih took the cake: the worst professor ive had at u of t in all four years. absolute lack of joy for material, hyper academic fluff. approach is devoid of any depth beyond elitist criticism. lectures consist of nothing more than a self-indulgent exercise in rhetoric. elaborates on basic concepts. antagonistic towards students
Excellent Prof. Very helpful. Encouraged and valued student input. To get the most out of her class, it really helps to participate.
she knows her stuff

I agree with the past comments about her lectures, too much discussion and encyclopaedic information.  Still, if a good, academic discussion does get going, it can be quite interesting as she really engages her students. She is a tough marker and I think that some of the requirements for the assignments are unnecessarily strict.

Extremely articulate and insightful about the novels she dissects, but tends to overanaylze the political aspect of them as opposed to the literary one. Fair marker; encourages student participation but does not take to ignorant comments very kindly.

Sara Salih, is a competent professor but not particularly challenging. Most of her discussions abotu the novels consist of wishy-washy generalized statements that most people can deduce by themselves. She can be quite rude to students and asks for participation but always calls on the teachers pets to speak.
i found sara salih to be very challenging and my mark wasn't stupendous, but i really enjoyed the class and learned a lot. she takes what she does very seriously so there's no room for laziness.

Prof. Salih is undoubtedly one of the most intelligent profs I've ever had, and really knows her suff...which is great, but I still think she needs to work on her personal approach with students. She's quite intimidating and can be snippy. Take a class w/ her if you're up to the challenge!
expects a lot of you but good. she knows her stuff & always makes the books seem better than they first appear.
The best professor I've ever had. Really knows her stuff, and very funny, in that dry English way. Always makes you think about things differently. Really an eye-opening course for me.

She gave me a 48% and refused to bump it.My father just had a heart attack and I missed class to be with him in intensive care. She's unsympathetic. She made me so nervous when I went to speak to her about my mark I had a serious panic attack. Avoid her!

She tries too much to prove a point that her British system is better that the Candian system and is very arrogant an marks down students because of the very high attitude the course is good but do it with another professor if you must.
A very good professor. Always pushes you to a deeper level, a more difficult question.  Her classes are a challenge but she breeds a respect in her students that makes you want to do well.
She focuses on political issues in the novel, not the language itself.  She tends to be rather critical, too.  She knows her stuff very well.
